snippet: Philanthropists invest for profit to sustain and grow resources available for the social sector.
abstract: Philanthropists invest for profit to sustain and grow resources available for the social sector.
lead_paragraph: “When the W. K. Kellogg Foundation set aside $100 million in 2007 to invest in companies that could produce both social and financial benefits, it was considered revolutionary,” Stephanie Strom wrote in the DealBook blog, but today such investments have become commonplace.

headline.main: In New Brand of Philanthropy, Nonprofits Invest in For-Profits
